subject: Writing
title: Logos: The Logic of Argument
description: A micro-lesson that makes Logos: The Logic of Argument usable.

hook.text: If all humans are mortal and Socrates is human, then Socrates is mortal. That chain of reasoning is logos.

buildup.text: Logos uses evidence, data, and logical reasoning to build a case that appears irrefutable.

discovery.text: Syllogisms, analogies, and inductive reasoning are all logos tools â€” they make arguments feel inevitable.

twist.text: Logos can be deceptive. A logical-sounding argument with a false premise leads to a convincing but wrong conclusion.

climax.text: Statistics are the modern weapon of logos â€” but numbers can mislead when presented without context.

punchline.text: Logic is powerful. But logic built on lies is a trap.

quiz.question: What is the risk of logos-based arguments?
options: False premises can lead to convincing but wrong conclusions
They are always too complicated to understand
They never work on emotional audiences
